title: Can I make lower payments on a loan than the minimum to keep from being served court papers & does the loan co have to accept it
question: I have a loan and am behind payments due to a job lay off in the family. They are going to serve me with court papers. If I make some smaller monthly payments than the minimum monthly payments, will this keep them from taking me to court and do they have to accept my smaller payments? Thank you.
answers: No, they don't have to accept your less-than-minimum payments ... and just because they do doesn't mean they won't sue you for breaching your contract.

Oh man, this is sticky. Part of the answer depends on how much "smaller" your payment is.
First, the technical rule: If you make payments less than the minimum payment, they have the right to just take you to court. full-stop.

Now, the Minutiae. There are a lot of factors to consider when trying to determine if the creditor will sue you or let it slide. What kind of creditor is it? Who is the creditor? How much smaller? Lets say it's a payday loan. They'll probably come after you. Because that's what they do. Also, what do you mean "smaller"? Lets say your minimum payment is $50. are you going to pay $49? what's the story. There's a lot of moving parts to the answer. But the short answer is: they have the right to just go to court.

NO.. You cannot unilaterally change the terms of your contract. Can they accept less? yes..but by agreement. Will they? Only they know. Filing bankruptcy will stop all legal action though and if you have a house don't let them get a judgment lien ! I suggest you discuss with a bankruptcy attorney on ALL your debts. But if you sold a car to someone for $2000 at $200 a month, do you think they can just say they want to pay your $25 a month ? You can see why that does not work!

Other issues and facts can also affect your case so I will point some of those out for you next too.

You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an
attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping
everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts. If you don't have any of the
exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523
(Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and
presumption of student loans. But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so
you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!
Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your
state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but
your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity
thereof!
Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your
options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you
have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply
with your attorney too.
But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a
relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that
relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the
bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so
meet with one no matter what.
Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one
as soon as you can.
You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of waiting versus filing now
and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.
